body:
Comment 9 by **schwehr**: 
I definitely think these are real issues and that this bug should be re-opened. 
Especially if the go team is trying to get new folks into go.

And to re-iterate 6959, it would be a big help for the folks who are new to the
community if the package looks as standard as possible.  go is definitely an odd package
release compared to other languages.  I don't like dealing with un packaged blobs and
it's not easy to follow or understand what go is trying to do. 

*)  It would be much better if go came out as go-x.y.z.tar.{gz,bz2,xz} and they untar'ed
to go-x.y.z.  c.f. python:

wget http://www.python.org/ftp/python/3.3.3/Python-3.3.3.tar.xz
tar tf Python-3.3.3.tar.xz | grep 'Python-3.3.3/README$'
Python-3.3.3/README

or ruby

tar tf /sw/src/ruby-2.0.0-p247.tar.bz2 | egrep 'ruby-2.0.0-p247/README'
ruby-2.0.0-p247/README.EXT
ruby-2.0.0-p247/README.EXT.ja
ruby-2.0.0-p247/README.ja
ruby-2.0.0-p247/README

*) There really should be an top level INSTALL file that points right to the
doc/install-source.html in the source tree.  Cause your install process is not like any
of the most common ones (autoconf, cmake, scons, etc).

As someone who builds tons of stuff, when I see something very unusual like "make.bash"
I would normally take that as a signal that I'm going hit all kinds of strange build
issues.

*) Things like pointing to http://golang.org/  are not winning the hearts and minds of
people interested in learning go (well, at least speaking for myself).
